awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Portable Oxygen Concentrator with High Flow Rates for In-home Therapy (COVID-19)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable easy oxygen delivery to patients with respiratory conditions.  Currently, patients requiring high flow-rates of oxygen above 4 L/min require oxygen tanks that are large, heavy and can be hazardous, limiting mobility and transportation options. The proposed system produces breathable oxygen at higher flow rates and lower energy compared to current portable oxygen concentrators, enabling sustained patient use. This enables sustained oxygen production in a portable manner to manage medical conditions causing oxygen deprivation, including Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19). 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a portable system that utilizes a novel photocatalytic (light activated) reaction to separate oxygen from ambient air, trapped in a chemical solution, then released as needed through a temperature-controlled reaction. This project will monitor the capture and release reactions using absorption spectroscopy to determine the ideal conditions of oxygen production. Several photosensitizer chemical compounds (fullerene C70 and C60, rubrene, and methylene blue with urea) will be evaluated on system longevity by continuously cycling the systems under higher temperatures and light exposure, and monitoring their effects on oxygen production. A prototype will then be developed that generates targeted oxygen flow rates at the desired rate of energy consumption, and the oxygen produced validated as safe for inhalation using bench tests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Project determined the effect of changing conditions for the novel, patent-pending photochemical process that can finally give high-flow oxygen patients the peace of mind and independence of a portable oxygen concentrator. Currently available portable oxygen concentrators are based on the decades-old pressure swing adsorption (PSA) technology with limited oxygen concentrations (90-93%) and flow rates (<1.5 L O2/min pulse flow).  Patients who need more than 1.5 L/min of oxygen must rely on cylinders of compressed oxygen and/or larger, stationary oxygen concentrators. The technology in this project can generate higher oxygen purity (99+% vs 90-93%) and flow rates (>6 L/min continuous flow vs. <1.5 L/min pulse flow) in the same physical footprint as legacy, pressure swing adsorption (PSA) concentrators. It will also enable utra-portable oxygen concentrators that can meet the lower oxygen flow rates of existing PSA concentrators with a much smaller and lighter device.

The photochemical solution developed in this Project consists of a Catalyst, Photosensitizer, and Solvent. The reaction includes two steps, oxygen capture and oxygen release. Oxygen capture is favored when the photochemical solution is cooled while exposed to air and light. With photoexcitation of the photosensitizer, which in turns creates the excited state of oxygen, singlet oxygen. Singlet oxygen reacts with the catalyst to make an endoperoxide, effectively storing the oxygen. Under dark and warm conditions the reverse reaction is favored, resulting in oxygen release. In this Project, both the oxygen capture and release reactions occurred in a single-vessel, batch reactor prototype.

The project objectives were:

  • Objective 1:  Optimize photochemical solution and process for oxygen capture and release
  • Objective 2:  Determine stability over time of solution components
  • Objective 3:  Develop a continuous flow prototype and determine energy requirements

This Project achieved several Objectives to move this technology closer to market. First, solution components were improved, replacing the original solvent and photosensitizer to achieve higher performance and increased safety. Second, the relative concentrations of  Catalyst and Photosensitizer were varied to maximize oxygen capture and release. Third, the optimal operating temperature range was narrowed, reducing the energy required to cool and warm the solution. Finally, the stability over time of the components was determined, which is especially important for the Photosensitizer, the component most susceptible to degradation over time.

This Project sets the stage to replace the current, single-vessel, batch prototype with a continuous flow design that will lead to a market-ready prototype that can achieve 6.0 L/min of 99%+ oxygen. In order to generate a continuous flow of oxygen, the photochemical solution will continuously cycle between oxygen capture and oxygen release sections of the next generations of prototypes. Although  a continuous flow prototype was developed during this Project, consistent capture and release oxygen was not realized due to difficulty in controlling all reaction conditions Future work will refine the design to reach the theoretic predicted flow-rates of the device.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2024
Modified by: Jun   Kamata
